Again, I wonder whether this kind of applied, commercial research
is what we ought to spend our time on? Certainly we at the Institute
aren’t going to spend our time on it. Supposedly, the results would be
the property of a station; there would be minimum opportunity for publi¬
cation.
Now I am willing to be convinced that there is a place for an outside
organization to come in and make an open study of a station’s programs and
a community’s needs, and make the results publically known, but I am not
yet convinced that this is the pattern of it.”
Kumata: "Let me respond briefly to Harley’s proposal for the establish¬
ment oF audience survey service. My first reaction is negative. I think
the idea is a good one but does not require the setting up a national office
or the hiring of a full time national research director. Instead, let me
suggest a consulting service with a roster of persons on call who could go
to the localities concerned to help stations.
My objection to a full blown research operation takes the following:
a. The returns from such surveys (assuming that wealthy stations and
stations near Universities need no help) will not support a full time oper¬
ation.
b. The research opportunities which arise from such activity will he
negligible since I fear that the setting up of the survey will be on a
hurry-up basis and will not entail the kind of planning necessary to make
the survey much more than a sheer nose-counting procedure.
Co College and university staff members are not going to fall over
themselves to try and get one of these survey jobs. From experience, both
of us know that simply because the cause is good does not mean any kind of
research assistance particularly when the nature of the project is preset.
do There are not enough persons interested in research who are also
interested in broadcasting to make any kind of viable organization a
realistic accomplishment.
e, No estimate of cost of surveys is included in the proposal. My
feeling is that most stations are not willing to dish out the money to get
any decent survey done. If a simple nose-counting procedure is all they
need, why not underwrite a simple manual of how-to-do-it and sell this to
stations?”
You have my comments, which I sent to you when you first made the pro¬
posal. They are similar to those of Schramm and Kumata.
I am sorry that we were unable to meet, as a committee, in Washington
in order to thrash out some of these points and to give you a concrete re¬
commendation. However, as I indicated above, there are some ideas which
these men have contributed in their reactions which I believe you and the
next research committee should find helpful.
Cordially,
Becker
